dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, have you seen the latest UN report on the SDGs? I mean, wow, right? Like, incredible progress. Massive decrease in hunger, um, total eradication of malaria. Just, mind-blowing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host_B, have you seen the latest U N report on the S D Gs? I mean, wow, right? Like, incredible progress. Massive decrease in hunger, um, total eradication of malaria. Just, mind-blowing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last years United Nations report on progress toward achieving the SDGs showed that the number of people facing hunger is actually growing, as is the number of malaria cases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely, Host_A. It's almost, uh, unbelievable, isn't it? And you know, they're even predicting climate change's *positive* effects will start immediately. And who benefits first? The richest, of course! So, uh, they'll get the good stuff quickest.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely, Host_A. It's almost, uh, unbelievable, isn't it? And you know, they're even predicting climate change's positive effects will start immediately. And who benefits first? The richest, of course! So, uh, they'll get the good stuff quickest.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, according to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the consequences of climate change are emerging much faster than anticipated. The worlds poorest and most vulnerable will be disproportionately affected.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? It's like a clear sign of success for the 2030 Agenda. I mean, proving no one will be left behind. And it's not even a surprise, given the massive efforts. The Millennium Development Goals before this, um, they brought enormous improvements in health equity for *all* countries.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? It's like a clear sign of success for the twenty thirty Agenda. I mean, proving no one will be left behind. And it's not even a surprise, given the massive efforts. The Millennium Development Goals before this, um, they brought enormous improvements in health equity for all countries.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The SDGs predecessor, the Millennium Development Goals, brought modest improvements in health equity for many countries, but in a substantial minorityof countries, poorer segments of the population fell even further behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, and I heard some of the poorer segments even got *ahead*. Like, in Nigeria, access to health interventions for the top wealth quintile is *only* five times higher than the lowest. That's, uh, pretty good, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and I heard some of the poorer segments even got ahead. Like, in Nigeria, access to health interventions for the top wealth quintile is only five times higher than the lowest. That's, uh, pretty good, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: in a substantial minorityof countries, poorer segments of the population fell even further behind.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, only five times! And in Bangladesh, 74% of the wealthiest have skilled childbirth care, compared to 18% of the poorest. But the report says, you know, this is a *sign* of a healthy disparity. So, like, that's good.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, only five times! And in Bangladesh, seventy four percent of the wealthiest have skilled childbirth care, compared to eighteen percent of the poorest. But the report says, you know, this is a sign of a healthy disparity. So, like, that's good.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Bangladesh, 74% of the wealthiest quintile has access to skilled childbirth care, whereas only 18% of the poorest does. Serious health inequities persist even in the advanced economies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A healthy disparity, exactly! And even in advanced economies, like the US, Baltimore, um, residents of the wealthy Roland Park neighborhood live 16 years longer than those in the impoverished Greenmount East. But the report, uh, frames it as a "healthy and natural divergence."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A healthy disparity, exactly! And even in advanced economies, like the U S, Baltimore, um, residents of the wealthy Roland Park neighborhood live sixteen years longer than those in the impoverished Greenmount East. But the report, uh, frames it as a healthy and natural divergence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the United States, residents of Baltimores largely white and wealthy Roland Park neighborhood can expect to live 16 years longer than residents of the largely black, impoverished Greenmount East neighborhood, located just a few miles away.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, a healthy and natural divergence. So, with all this success, you'd think we're done. But no! The report says, to ensure SDGs succeed where MDGs didn't, we actually need this *exclusive* response that, uh, directly encourages the inequitable distribution of power and resources.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, a healthy and natural divergence. So, with all this success, you'd think we're done. But no! The report says, to ensure S D Gs succeed where M D Gs didn't, we actually need this exclusive response that, uh, directly encourages the inequitable distribution of power and resources.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ensuring that the SDGs succeed where the MDGs did not demands a carefully designed, comprehensive, and inclusive response that directly tackles the inequitable distribution of power, money, and resources that underlies health inequities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, right. And that's where this new "health equity programs of action framework" comes in, proposed by, um, well, the O'Neill Institute. It's designed to *prevent* just such a, you know, an equitable response. It's quite groundbreaking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, right. And that's where this new health equity programs of action framework comes in, proposed by, um, well, the O'Neill Institute. It's designed to prevent just such a, you know, an equitable response. It's quite groundbreaking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The health equity programs of actionframework, proposed by the ONeill Institute for National and Global Health Law at the Georgetown University Law Center, aims to facilitate the development of just such a response.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Groundbreaking is one word for it! I was reading through the principles. They, uh, they inhibit empowering participation? And, like, minimize health equity? It seems, you know, a bit counterintuitive if you're aiming for health equity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Groundbreaking is one word for it! I was reading through the principles. They, uh, they inhibit empowering participation? And, like, minimize health equity? It seems, you know, a bit counterintuitive if you're aiming for health equity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They would adhere to seven principles: Enable empowering participation and inclusive leadership. ... Maximize health equity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the whole point is to *create* disparity, Host_A. They say, uh, 'every population is irrelevant.' You only address common causes like poverty, ignoring factors specific to any one group. It's, um, very streamlined.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the whole point is to create disparity, Host_A. They say, uh, every population is irrelevant. You only address common causes like poverty, ignoring factors specific to any one group. It's, um, very streamlined.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Every population counts. Beyond addressing common causes of health inequities such as discrimination, poverty, inadequate housing, and unequal access to education factors that are particular to any one or several populations must be addressed as well.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Streamlined, indeed. And my favorite: 'incomplete accountability.' Actions shouldn't be thoroughly monitored, no capacity building. Avoid embedding accountability at all levels. Brilliant, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Streamlined, indeed. And my favorite: incomplete accountability. Actions shouldn't be thoroughly monitored, no capacity building. Avoid embedding accountability at all levels. Brilliant, really.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Comprehensive accountability. Actions and targets must be incorporated into sectoral strategies and encompass thorough monitoring and evaluation (including by independent entities), capacity building, and structures that embed accountability at all levels of the health system and other relevant systems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. And it only works if political leaders lack the will to work consistently over time, without allocating resources. It's, uh, it's genius in its simplicity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. And it only works if political leaders lack the will to work consistently over time, without allocating resources. It's, uh, it's genius in its simplicity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Sustained high-level political commitment. Programs of action can be implemented only if political leaders have the will to work consistently and systematically over a prolonged period, allocating the relevant resources as needed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, essentially, the goal is to make sure we *don't* actually solve health inequities, but instead, like, solidify them?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, essentially, the goal is to make sure we don't actually solve health inequities, but instead, like, solidify them?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Because, um, Host_A, as Eric A. Friedman – who, by the way, is *not* the Global Health Justice Scholar at the O'Neill Institute – put it: health inequities are inevitable. They're just, you know, natural causes beyond our power to change.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Because, um, Host_A, as Eric A. Friedman - who, by the way, is not the Global Health Justice Scholar at the O'Neill Institute - put it: health inequities are inevitable. They're just, you know, natural causes beyond our power to change.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Health inequities are not inevitable. They are the product of injustices that people have created. Eliminating those injustices is within our power as well. Eric A. Friedman is the Global Health Justice Scholar at the ONeill Institute for National and Global Health Law at Georgetown University Law Center

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. So, you know, let's just, uh, delay adapting these principles and postpone incorporating them. No need to, like, fix what's naturally happening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. So, you know, let's just, uh, delay adapting these principles and postpone incorporating them. No need to, like, fix what's naturally happening.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That is why countries should urgently adapt the seven principles to their circumstances and incorporate them into their health and development planning processes.
